docs.lead_paragraph: More than 400 janitors in Fairfield County, Conn., agreed last night to end their six-week walkout by reaching a tentative three-year contract that will raise salaries for most of them by nearly 50 percent. The agreement, signed yesterday in the office of Stamford's mayor, ended a highly charged dispute that involved repeated sit-ins, more than 50 arrests and a three-week fast by four strikers.

headline.main: Deal Ends Strike by Fairfield County Janitors

docs.abstract: Six-week walkout by janitors in Fairfield County, Conn, ends after tentative three-year contract is reached; agreement will raise wages of most of county's office building janitors by nearly 50 percent; most employees are not in union but under terms of agreement can join as soon as majority of janitors at work site sign cards saying they want to join; union officials are optimistic that nearly all janitors will join Service Employees Union by end of year; many part-time jobs will be converted to full time, but union failed to get health insurance coverage for part-time workers (M)
docs.snippet: More than 400 janitors in Fairfield County, Conn., agreed last night to end their six-week walkout by reaching a tentative three-year contract that will raise salaries for most of them by nearly 50 percent.     The agreement, signed yesterday in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Worried about safety and rising drug costs, a small but growing number of hospitals, clinics and other health care organizations across the country are banning free samples of brand name prescription drugs, or limiting what samples their doctors can accept from drug companies. Doctors have long used free drug samples to let patients try new treatments or to start patients on medications quickly while they are waiting for prescriptions to be filled. But now, doctors, administrators and pharmacists at hospitals in cities including Madison, Wis., and Everett, Wash., say they worry they cannot control the increasing amount of free medicines that are doled out by pharmaceutical representatives.

headline.main: Growing Opposition To Free Drug Samples; Ultimate Costs and Safety Are Cited

docs.abstract: Small but growing number of hospitals, clinics and other health care organizations across the country, worried about safety and rising drug costs, are banning free samples of brand name prescription drugs, or limiting what samples their doctors can accept from drug companies; doctors, administrators and pharmacists at hospitals say they worry they cannot control increasing amount of free medicines that are doled out by pharmaceutical representatives; health care administrators assert that samples are helping to inflate their drug costs because drug companies tend to give out samples of newest brand name drugs, which are often most expensive; Dr John Chessare, chief medical officer of Boston Medical Center, and Dr Finley W Brown Jr, private physician in Chicago, comment; graph; photos (M)
